Introduction to main functions of the ETN package

Stijn Van Hoey

2018-05-31

Source: vignettes/etn-overview.Rmd
etn-overview.Rmd

Introduction

The etn package provides a set of get_*-based functions to access the ETN data and metadata. In this vignette a quick overview of these main functions is given. As the access to data is linked to specific user profiles, keep in mind that the results can be different for other users.

To start, load the package:

library(etn)

When not installed, do not forget to install the package using the devtools package:

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("inbo/etn")

The database connection

In order to access the data, the first step is always to connect with your user credentials (as received by VLIZ) to the database.

my_con <- connect_to_etn(Sys.getenv("userid"),
                         Sys.getenv("pwd"))
my_con
#> <OdbcConnection> damiano.oldoni@inbo.be@dppg.vliz.be
#>   Database: ETN
#>   PostgreSQL Version: 9.6.9

Remark that for this example, we load the user credentials as environmental variables by saving an .Renviron file in the home directory with the username and password stored. Other options are available as well, as explained here.

Once the connection established, the get_* functions can be used to effectively access the data. Each of these functions have a (valid database) connection as first input.

Notice, that you can find the get_*-functions inside Rstudio by typing: etn::get_* + TAB button.

Metadata

Project overview

To get a full overview of the projects you have access to, use the function get_projects():

my_projects <- get_projects(my_con)
head(my_projects, 10) # print 10 first
#>     id             name    projectcode    type  startdate    enddate
#> 1  638        Lifewatch cpod-lifewatch network       <NA>       <NA>
#> 2    3        Lifewatch      lifewatch network       <NA>       <NA>
#> 3  620   Noordzeekanaal Noordzeekanaal network 2017-09-13       <NA>
#> 4  617             PC4C           pc4c network 2017-07-03       <NA>
#> 5  625     Deveron 2016        Deveron network 2016-04-01 2016-07-01
#> 6  626 Moray Firth 2016     MorayFirth network 2016-04-01 2016-07-01
#> 7  627    Aberdeen 2017       Aberdeen network 2017-08-01 2017-12-22
#> 8  628       Conon 2017          Conon network 2016-04-01 2016-07-01
#> 9  629        Skye 2017           Skye network 2017-04-01 2017-08-15
#> 10 599          Homarus        homarus  animal       <NA>       <NA>
#>    moratorium imis_dataset_id latitude longitude
#> 1           0              NA       NA        NA
#> 2           0              NA       NA        NA
#> 3           0            5881       NA        NA
#> 4           0            5848       NA        NA
#> 5           0            5913       NA        NA
#> 6           0            5914       NA        NA
#> 7           0            5915       NA        NA
#> 8           0            5916       NA        NA
#> 9           0            5917       NA        NA
#> 10          0              NA       NA        NA

As projects are defined both on the level of the animal as well as the network, a column type is available that defines the type of project (animal or network). Still, one can also directly subset by adding the type as input argument, e.g.Â for network:

my_network_projects <- get_projects(my_con, project_type = "network")
head(my_network_projects, 10) # print 10 first
#>     id             name    projectcode    type  startdate    enddate
#> 1  638        Lifewatch cpod-lifewatch network       <NA>       <NA>
#> 2    3        Lifewatch      lifewatch network       <NA>       <NA>
#> 3  620   Noordzeekanaal Noordzeekanaal network 2017-09-13       <NA>
#> 4  617             PC4C           pc4c network 2017-07-03       <NA>
#> 5  625     Deveron 2016        Deveron network 2016-04-01 2016-07-01
#> 6  626 Moray Firth 2016     MorayFirth network 2016-04-01 2016-07-01
#> 7  627    Aberdeen 2017       Aberdeen network 2017-08-01 2017-12-22
#> 8  628       Conon 2017          Conon network 2016-04-01 2016-07-01
#> 9  629        Skye 2017           Skye network 2017-04-01 2017-08-15
#> 10  13             Maas           maas network       <NA>       <NA>
#>    moratorium imis_dataset_id latitude longitude
#> 1           0              NA       NA        NA
#> 2           0              NA       NA        NA
#> 3           0            5881       NA        NA
#> 4           0            5848       NA        NA
#> 5           0            5913       NA        NA
#> 6           0            5914       NA        NA
#> 7           0            5915       NA        NA
#> 8           0            5916       NA        NA
#> 9           0            5917       NA        NA
#> 10          0              NA       NA        NA

Receiver overview

A network project typically considers multiple receivers that are placed on specific locations to lay out the network. To get an overview of the receivers or those linked to specific projects, use the get_receivers function:

ws3_receivers <- get_receivers(my_con, network_project = "ws3")
head(ws3_receivers, 10) # print 10 first
#>    serial_number model_number modem_address expected_battery_life

You can also define multiple (network) projects at the same time, by combining them in a vector:

ws_receivers <- get_receivers(my_con, network_project = c("ws1", "ws3"))
head(ws_receivers, 10) # print 10 first
#>    serial_number model_number modem_address expected_battery_life
#> 1         545588        VR2AR          <NA>                  <NA>
#> 2         123818         VR2W          <NA>                  <NA>

When a number of columns is not useful to your specific purpose, remember that the output is a data.frame, which can be filtered and subsetted conveniently with for example the dplyr functions.

library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

For example, selecting only the columns serial_number, receiver and status:

ws_receivers %>% 
  select(serial_number, receiver, status) %>%
  head(10) # print 10 first
#>    serial_number     receiver                   status
#> 1         545588 VR2AR-545588 Returned to manufacturer
#> 2         123818  VR2W-123818                   Active
#> 3         123813  VR2W-123813                   Active
#> 4         123813  VR2W-123813                   Active
#> 5         123813  VR2W-123813                   Active
#> 6         123821  VR2W-123821                     Lost
#> 7         127733  VR2W-127733                   Active
#> 8         123815  VR2W-123815                   Active
#> 9         123817  VR2W-123817                Available
#> 10        127725  VR2W-127725                   Active

Deployments overview

Receivers are deployed for a specific period and this deployment information can be accessed as well with the command get_deployments. Filtering on the network project is similar to get_receivers and as the information about the receiver status is crucial, the function provides an additional argument to query based on the receiver status. Getting an overview of the lost and broken receivers of a specific project:

my_deployments <- get_deployments(my_con, network_project = "ws1", 
                                  receiver_status = c("Broken", "Lost"))
head(my_deployments, 10) # print 10 first 
#>  [1] receiver                      receiver_status              
#>  [3] projectname                   projectcode                  
#>  [5] projectmember                 drop_dead_date               
#>  [7] download_date_time            deploy_date_time             
#>  [9] recover_date_time             bottom_depth                 
#> [11] riser_length                  instrument_depth             
#> [13] check_complete_time           sync_date_time               
#> [15] voltage_at_deploy             ar_confirm                   
#> [17] data_downloaded               voltage_at_download          
#> [19] time_drift                    comments                     
#> [21] id_pk                         receiver_fk                  
#> [23] location_name                 location_manager             
#> [25] location_description          deploy_lat                   
#> [27] deploy_long                   recover_lat                  
#> [29] recover_long                  station_name                 
#> [31] intended_lat                  intended_long                
#> [33] date_created                  date_modified                
#> [35] battery_install_date          ar_battery_install_date      
#> [37] distance_to_mouth             source                       
#> [39] transmit_profile              transmit_power_output        
#> [41] log_temperature_stats_period  log_temperature_sample_period
#> [43] log_tilt_sample_period        log_noise_stats_period       
#> [45] log_noise_sample_period       log_depth_stats_period       
#> [47] log_depth_sample_period       project_fk                   
#> [49] mooring_type                  deployment_type              
#> [51] activation_datetime           valid_data_until_datetime    
#> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)

Animals overview

Within an animal project, multiple animals are provided with a transmitter. The metadata of these animals is requested with the function get_animals. As animals can be part of both network and animal projects, both can be used to filter the results.

As such, selecting the animals metadata for the 2012_leopoldkanaal project:

my_animals <- get_animals(my_con, animal_project = "2012_leopoldkanaal")
head(my_animals, 10) # print 10 first
#>           projectname projectmember tag_code_space person_id animal_id
#> 1  2012 Leopoldkanaal             1 A69-1601-31854        20      <NA>
#> 2  2012 Leopoldkanaal             1 A69-1601-31855        20      <NA>

When interested in specific species, add the scientific name as argument.

Transmitter overview

The transmitters/tags metadata can be accessed by the get_transmitters function, with the option to subset on the animal project names:

my_tags <- get_transmitters(my_con, animal_project = "phd_reubens")
head(my_tags, 10) # print 10 first
#>    serial_number     type  model id_code tag_code_space    owner_pi id_pk

Detections data

The raw detections are the core for any type of analysis and access is provided by the get_detections function. Different filters are available which you can explore by typing ?get_detections in the console.

To narrow down the data request, filters are provided on animal/network project name, the deployment station name and the transmitter identifier to narrow. Furthermore, as these data sets can be large, some additional time-based filters are provided with a start_date and an end_date:

my_detections <- get_detections(my_con, animal_project = "phd_reubens", 
                                start_date = "2011-01-28", end_date = "2011-02-01")
#> Note: method with signature 'DBIConnection#SQL' chosen for function 'dbQuoteString',
#>  target signature 'PostgreSQL#SQL'.
#>  "OdbcConnection#character" would also be valid
head(my_detections, 10) # print 10 first

The date level can be defined on month (e.g. "2011-01") or year (e.g. "2011") level as well. Finally, for explorative reasons, a hard maximum limit of records to request can help to have a quick glance on the expected data.

See more exampled in the function help (remember the ?get_detections).
